policies.name: Access Control Policy
policies.description: Organizational policy governing all access control practices including account management, authorization processes, and access enforcement
policies.rationale: NIST 03.01.01 requires managing system accounts 'in accordance with policy, procedures, prerequisites, and criteria' necessitating formal policy guidance

policies.name: Account Management Policy
policies.description: Specific policy defining types of accounts allowed and prohibited, account lifecycle management requirements, and notification timelines
policies.rationale: Control requirement (a) explicitly requires defining 'types of system accounts allowed and prohibited' which necessitates documented policy

procedures.name: Account Provisioning Procedure
procedures.description: Step-by-step process for creating, enabling, modifying accounts including authorization requirements, approval workflows, and access assignment criteria
procedures.rationale: Control requirement (b) requires creating and enabling accounts 'in accordance with procedures' and requirement (d) requires 'valid access authorization' before granting access

procedures.name: Account Deprovisioning Procedure
procedures.description: Process for disabling and removing accounts including triggers for deactivation, notification requirements, and timeline specifications
procedures.rationale: Control requirement (f) requires disabling accounts under specific conditions and (g) requires notifications within defined timeframes

procedures.name: Account Review Procedure
procedures.description: Process for periodic review of active accounts, group memberships, and access authorizations including review frequency, responsibilities, and remediation steps
procedures.rationale: Control requirement (e) requires 'monitor the use of system accounts' which necessitates defined monitoring and review procedures

executionEvidence.name: Quarterly Account Review Reports
executionEvidence.description: Reports showing: list of all accounts reviewed, group and role memberships validated, inactive accounts identified (with last login date), unauthorized or excessive privileges removed, accounts disabled per policy criteria, reviewer name and signature, date review completed
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST requires monitoring account use (requirement e) and CIS Benchmark recommends quarterly access reviews; accounts not reviewed within 120 days indicate gap in monitoring controls

executionEvidence.name: Account Creation/Modification Tickets
executionEvidence.description: Helpdesk or IAM system tickets showing: requester name, account details, access level requested, business justification, approver name and approval date, date processed, system access granted
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates compliance with requirements (b), (c), and (d) requiring proper authorization and specification of access rights before account creation or modification

executionEvidence.name: Terminated Employee Account Deactivation Records
executionEvidence.description: Records showing: employee name, termination date, accounts disabled, date accounts disabled, HR notification received date, gaps between termination and deactivation, approver confirmation
executionEvidence.rationale: Requirement (g)(2) requires notification and action when 'users are terminated or transferred'; industry best practice is 24-hour deactivation to prevent unauthorized access

executionEvidence.name: Inactive Account Deactivation Reports
executionEvidence.description: Reports showing: accounts with no login activity exceeding organization-defined period (typically 90 days), date last login, date account disabled, exceptions documented with approvals
executionEvidence.rationale: Requirement (f)(2) requires disabling accounts 'inactive for organization-defined time period'; monthly reviews prevent accumulation of stale accounts posing security risk

executionEvidence.name: Account Manager Notification Logs
executionEvidence.description: Logs showing: notification sent to account managers, event triggering notification (expiration, termination, role change), date notification sent, recipient confirmation, action taken with date
executionEvidence.rationale: Requirement (g) mandates notifications to account managers within defined timeframes for various account events; logs demonstrate compliance with notification requirements

executionEvidence.name: Privileged Account Approval Documentation
executionEvidence.description: Records showing: privileged access requests, business justification for elevated privileges, additional scrutiny review notes, approver name and date, periodic re-certification of need
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST Discussion states 'users who require administrative privileges receive additional scrutiny'; documentation proves enhanced review process for high-risk accounts

operationalActivities: Define and document allowed and prohibited account types
Create new user accounts with proper authorization and approval
Modify account permissions based on role changes with authorization
Specify authorized users, group memberships, and privileges for each account
Authorize access based on valid authorization and intended system usage
Monitor active accounts and usage patterns
Disable accounts within 24 hours of employee termination
Disable accounts exceeding inactivity threshold (typically 90 days)
Disable accounts violating organizational policy
Remove accounts no longer associated with users
Notify account managers when accounts no longer required
Notify appropriate personnel of user terminations and transfers within defined timeframe
Notify managers of need-to-know changes within defined timeframe
Review all active accounts quarterly for appropriateness
Apply additional scrutiny to privileged account requests

policies.name: Access Control Policy
policies.description: Comprehensive organizational policy defining access control requirements, enforcement mechanisms, and applicable access control models (RBAC, MAC, DAC)
policies.rationale: NIST 03.01.02 requires enforcing 'approved authorizations in accordance with applicable access control policies' and Discussion states 'access control policies are defined in 03.15.01'

procedures.name: Access Authorization Procedure
procedures.description: Process for determining and approving logical access rights to CUI and system resources based on job roles, business need, and security clearances
procedures.rationale: Control requires enforcing 'approved authorizations' which necessitates documented process for determining what constitutes an approved authorization

procedures.name: Access Enforcement Configuration Procedure
procedures.description: Technical procedure for implementing access controls in systems, applications, and network devices including RBAC configuration, permission assignment, and enforcement verification
procedures.rationale: NIST Discussion states 'access enforcement mechanisms can be employed at the application and service levels' requiring documented technical implementation procedures

executionEvidence.name: Access Control Configuration Exports
executionEvidence.description: System exports showing: user accounts, assigned roles and groups, resource permissions, access control lists (ACLs), file and folder permissions, database access rights, export date and system covered
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates actual enforcement of approved authorizations; monthly exports enable detection of unauthorized permission changes or privilege creep

executionEvidence.name: Access Authorization Approval Records
executionEvidence.description: Records showing: access requests, resources requested, business justification, approver review and decision, date approved/denied, access level granted matching request
executionEvidence.rationale: Proves access enforcement is based on 'approved authorizations' as required by control; creates audit trail linking granted access to formal approvals

executionEvidence.name: Remote Access Authorization and Enforcement Records
executionEvidence.description: Logs showing: VPN connections with user authentication, conditional access policy enforcement, MFA verification, access denied events with reasons, remote sessions to CUI systems
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST Discussion specifically mentions 'types of system access include remote access'; logs prove enforcement of access policies for external connections

executionEvidence.name: Failed Access Attempt Logs
executionEvidence.description: Security logs showing: unauthorized access attempts, access denied events, user attempting access, resource accessed, reason for denial, timestamp, follow-up investigation for repeated failures
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates active enforcement of access control policies by blocking unauthorized attempts; critical for identifying potential security incidents requiring rapid review

executionEvidence.name: Application-Level Access Control Audit Logs
executionEvidence.description: Application logs showing: user access to CUI data within applications, enforced permissions by role, data access requests and approvals, enforcement of segregation of duties, query-level access controls
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST Discussion states enforcement mechanisms 'can be employed at the application and service levels'; proves CUI protection extends beyond network and OS layers

operationalActivities: Define and approve access authorizations for all users and system processes
Configure and maintain role-based access controls (RBAC) in all systems
Enforce access controls at network, system, application, and data layers
Implement access enforcement for remote access and external connections
Block unauthorized access attempts to CUI and system resources
Monitor and log all access enforcement actions and denied attempts
Review access denied logs weekly for patterns requiring policy adjustment
Verify access enforcement configuration matches approved policies quarterly

policies.name: Information Flow Control Policy
policies.description: Policy defining approved information flows within systems and between connected systems, prohibited flows, CUI transmission requirements, and enforcement mechanisms
policies.rationale: NIST 03.01.03 requires enforcing 'approved authorizations for controlling the flow of CUI' necessitating policy defining what flows are approved

policies.name: Data Loss Prevention Policy
policies.description: Policy governing use of DLP technologies to prevent unauthorized CUI transmission via email, web, removable media, and cloud services
policies.rationale: NIST Discussion states enforcement occurs through 'message-filtering capability based on message content' which describes DLP functionality

policies.name: External Information Exchange Policy
policies.description: Policy governing CUI exchange with external organizations including agreement requirements referenced in 03.12.05
policies.rationale: NIST Discussion states 'transferring CUI between organizations may require an agreement that specifies how the information flow is enforced (see 03.12.05)'

procedures.name: Network Segmentation and Flow Control Procedure
procedures.description: Technical procedure for implementing network segmentation, firewall rules, router ACLs, and boundary protection devices to control CUI flows
procedures.rationale: NIST Discussion states enforcement occurs in 'boundary protection devices (e.g., encrypted tunnels, routers, gateways, and firewalls) that use rule sets or establish configuration settings'

procedures.name: Data Loss Prevention Configuration Procedure
procedures.description: Procedure for configuring and maintaining DLP policies, rules, and exceptions for CUI identification and flow control across communication channels
procedures.rationale: Control requires enforcement mechanisms; DLP provides 'message-filtering capability based on message content' as described in NIST Discussion

procedures.name: Encrypted Tunnel Configuration Procedure
procedures.description: Procedure for establishing and maintaining encrypted tunnels for authorized CUI flows between systems and external organizations
procedures.rationale: NIST Discussion mentions 'encrypted tunnels' as enforcement mechanism and states 'flow control restrictions include keeping CUI from being transmitted in the clear to the internet'

executionEvidence.name: Firewall and Router Rule Set Documentation
executionEvidence.description: Configuration exports showing: firewall rules controlling CUI flows, router ACLs, blocked traffic patterns, allowed information flows with justification, rule review date, configuration backup date
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST Discussion states enforcement occurs through 'rule sets or configuration settings'; quarterly reviews ensure rules still match approved information flows

executionEvidence.name: DLP Incident and Block Logs
executionEvidence.description: DLP system logs showing: attempted unauthorized CUI transmissions blocked, policy rule triggered, content type and sensitivity detected, user involved, destination blocked, incident disposition
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates active enforcement of information flow controls by preventing unauthorized CUI transmission; weekly review enables rapid incident response

executionEvidence.name: Network Flow Analysis Reports
executionEvidence.description: Reports showing: CUI data flows mapped within system, inter-system connections identified, unauthorized flow patterns detected, flows compared against approved authorization matrix
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST requires controlling flows 'within the system and between connected systems'; flow analysis proves enforcement matches approved authorizations

executionEvidence.name: External CUI Transfer Logs
executionEvidence.description: Logs showing: CUI transfers to external organizations, information exchange agreement referenced, encryption method used, authorized recipient verified, transfer approval documentation
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST Discussion states external transfers 'may require an agreement that specifies how the information flow is enforced'; logs prove compliance with agreement terms

executionEvidence.name: Network Segmentation Verification Reports
executionEvidence.description: Reports showing: network segments mapped, CUI systems isolated from public systems, VLAN configurations verified, subnet isolation tested, unauthorized connections blocked
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST Discussion mentions need to 'block external communications traffic that claims to be sourced from within the organization'; segmentation verification ensures isolation

operationalActivities: Define and document approved CUI information flows within and between systems
Configure firewalls and routers to enforce approved information flows
Implement DLP policies to prevent unauthorized CUI transmission
Establish encrypted tunnels for authorized external CUI transfers
Block CUI transmission in clear text to the internet
Block external traffic claiming to originate from internal network
Restrict internet requests to only those from internal web proxy
Monitor and log information flow enforcement actions daily
Review DLP incidents weekly and firewall logs monthly
Verify network segmentation quarterly for proper CUI isolation
Establish information exchange agreements before external CUI transfers

policies.name: Separation of Duties Policy
policies.description: Organizational policy defining duties requiring separation, incompatible function combinations, and enforcement through access controls
policies.rationale: NIST 03.01.04 requirement (a) explicitly requires 'identify the duties of individuals requiring separation' necessitating formal policy guidance

policies.name: Access Control Policy
policies.description: Policy addressing how separation of duties is enforced through system access authorizations and role definitions
policies.rationale: Control requirement (b) requires 'define system access authorizations to support separation of duties' which must be documented in access control policy

procedures.name: Duty Separation Analysis Procedure
procedures.description: Process for identifying conflicting duties, analyzing job functions for separation requirements, and documenting incompatible role combinations
procedures.rationale: Requirement (a) requires identifying duties requiring separation; systematic procedure ensures comprehensive analysis of organizational functions

procedures.name: Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) Design Procedure
procedures.description: Procedure for designing roles and access authorizations that enforce separation of duties including role conflict matrices and approval workflows
procedures.rationale: Requirement (b) requires defining 'system access authorizations to support separation of duties'; RBAC design prevents single users from holding conflicting roles

executionEvidence.name: Separation of Duties Matrix
executionEvidence.description: Documentation showing: incompatible duties identified, role combinations prohibited, users mapped to roles, conflicts checked, exceptions documented with compensating controls, last review date
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates compliance with requirement (a) to identify duties requiring separation; annual updates account for organizational changes while quarterly checks prevent drift

executionEvidence.name: Role Assignment Conflict Reports
executionEvidence.description: Reports showing: user role assignments checked against conflict matrix, violations identified, conflicting roles held by single users, remediation actions taken, compensating controls for approved exceptions
executionEvidence.rationale: Proves ongoing enforcement of defined separation requirements; quarterly checks detect unauthorized role combinations or privilege creep violating separation policies

executionEvidence.name: Access Control Configuration Demonstrating Separation
executionEvidence.description: System configuration exports showing: administrative functions separated from audit functions, quality assurance roles separated from development roles, security roles separated from operational roles, enforcement through RBAC permissions
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST Discussion requires 'personnel who administer access control functions do not also administer audit functions'; configuration proves technical enforcement

executionEvidence.name: Transaction Authorization and Approval Logs
executionEvidence.description: Logs showing: critical transactions requiring multiple approvals, initiator and approver are different individuals, segregation enforced for financial and security functions, override attempts logged and investigated
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates operational enforcement of separation preventing 'malevolent activity without collusion' as stated in NIST requirement; proves controls function in daily operations

operationalActivities: Identify all duties requiring separation across organization
Document incompatible function combinations in duty separation matrix
Define system roles that enforce separation of duties
Configure RBAC to prevent assignment of conflicting roles to single user
Separate administration of access controls from audit functions
Separate quality assurance roles from development roles
Separate security management roles from operations roles
Review user role assignments quarterly for conflicts
Investigate and remediate detected separation violations
Document approved exceptions with compensating controls
Update separation of duties matrix annually or when functions change

policies.name: Least Privilege Policy
policies.description: Organizational policy requiring minimum necessary access for all users and processes, defining security functions and security-relevant information requiring authorization
policies.rationale: NIST 03.01.05 requirement (b) requires authorizing access to 'organization-defined security functions and security-relevant information' necessitating policy definition

policies.name: Access Control Policy
policies.description: Policy establishing principles of least privilege across system development, implementation, and operations
policies.rationale: NIST Discussion states 'organizations employ the principle of least privilege for specific duties and authorized access for users and system processes'

procedures.name: Privilege Assignment Procedure
procedures.description: Process for determining minimum access required for organizational tasks, authorizing access to security functions, and limiting access to security-relevant information
procedures.rationale: Requirement (a) requires allowing 'only authorized system access that is necessary to accomplish assigned organizational tasks'; systematic procedure ensures consistent application

procedures.name: Privilege Review and Validation Procedure
procedures.description: Process for periodic review of assigned privileges, validation of continued need, and removal or reassignment of unnecessary privileges
procedures.rationale: Requirement (c) requires reviewing 'privileges assigned to roles or classes of users at organization-defined frequency to validate the need' and (d) requires 'reassign or remove privileges, as necessary'

executionEvidence.name: Privilege Inventory and Assignment Records
executionEvidence.description: Documentation showing: all user accounts and assigned privileges, job roles mapped to minimum required permissions, security function access authorizations, security-relevant information access lists, business justification for each privilege
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates implementation of requirement (a) allowing only necessary access; inventory enables systematic review required by requirement (c)

executionEvidence.name: Quarterly Privilege Review Reports
executionEvidence.description: Reports showing: privileges reviewed for each role and user class, validation of continued need documented, unnecessary privileges identified, privileges removed or reassigned, reviewer signature and date
executionEvidence.rationale: Requirement (c) explicitly requires reviews at 'organization-defined frequency to validate the need for such privileges'; quarterly reviews align with industry best practices

executionEvidence.name: Security Function Authorization Records
executionEvidence.description: Records showing: access to security functions (account management, software installation, audit configuration, vulnerability scanning, cryptographic key management), authorized personnel, approval documentation, periodic re-authorization
executionEvidence.rationale: Requirement (b) specifically requires authorizing access to security functions; NIST Discussion lists examples including 'establishing system accounts and assigning privileges, installing software'

executionEvidence.name: Privilege Removal Logs
executionEvidence.description: System logs showing: privileges removed when no longer needed, role changes triggering privilege removal, accounts downgraded from privileged to standard, justification for removal actions, date and administrator performing change
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates compliance with requirement (d) to 'reassign or remove privileges, as necessary'; logs prove responsive privilege management

executionEvidence.name: Excessive Privilege Detection Reports
executionEvidence.description: Reports showing: users with privileges exceeding role requirements, unused permissions identified through usage monitoring, excessive administrative rights detected, remediation actions and timelines
executionEvidence.rationale: Proactive identification of least privilege violations enables continuous compliance; monthly checks prevent privilege creep that undermines the control

operationalActivities: Apply least privilege principle to all system development and operations
Authorize only minimum access necessary for assigned organizational tasks
Define and document organization's security functions requiring authorization
Define and document security-relevant information requiring authorization
Review assigned privileges quarterly to validate continued need
Remove privileges immediately when no longer required for job role
Reassign privileges when job duties change
Monitor privilege usage to detect excessive or unused permissions
Create additional processes and roles as needed to achieve least privilege
Authorize access to security functions only to designated personnel
Restrict access to security-relevant information (cryptographic keys, audit data, security architecture, ACLs, vulnerability data)

policies.name: Privileged Account Management Policy
policies.description: Policy restricting privileged accounts to specific personnel or roles and requiring use of non-privileged accounts for non-security functions
policies.rationale: NIST 03.01.06 requirement (a) requires restricting 'privileged accounts on the system to organization-defined personnel or roles' necessitating policy defining who is authorized

policies.name: Privileged Access Policy
policies.description: Policy governing when compelling operational needs justify privileged account access to CUI and defining separation of privileged and non-privileged account usage
policies.rationale: Control title states 'authorize access to CUI for privileged accounts only when compelling operational needs require such access' requiring policy defining compelling needs

procedures.name: Privileged Account Request and Approval Procedure
procedures.description: Process for requesting privileged access including justification requirements, approval workflow, periodic re-certification, and access removal process
procedures.rationale: Requirement (a) requires restricting privileged accounts to defined personnel; formal procedure ensures consistent evaluation and approval of privileged access requests

procedures.name: Privileged Account Usage Procedure
procedures.description: Procedure requiring administrators to use standard accounts for routine work and privileged accounts only when performing security functions or accessing security-relevant information
procedures.rationale: Requirement (b) requires 'users with privileged accounts use non-privileged accounts when accessing non-security functions or non-security information'

executionEvidence.name: Privileged Account Inventory
executionEvidence.description: Comprehensive list showing: all privileged accounts (administrators, super users), account holder name and role, access level granted (domain admin, local admin, security function access), business justification for privileged access, approval documentation, last review date
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates restriction of privileged accounts to authorized personnel as required by (a); enables verification that only defined personnel/roles hold elevated privileges

executionEvidence.name: Privileged Account Approval and Justification Records
executionEvidence.description: Records showing: privileged access requests, compelling operational need documented, approver review notes, elevated scrutiny applied, approval or denial decision with rationale, effective and expiration dates
executionEvidence.rationale: Proves privileged access granted only when justified per control title; approval documentation demonstrates enhanced review before granting elevated privileges

executionEvidence.name: Privileged vs. Non-Privileged Account Usage Logs
executionEvidence.description: Authentication logs showing: privileged account logins only for administrative tasks, standard account usage for routine work (email, document editing, browsing), violations of separation detected, investigation records for improper privileged account use
executionEvidence.rationale: Requirement (b) mandates using non-privileged accounts for non-security functions; logs prove administrators follow procedure to separate privileged and standard account usage

executionEvidence.name: Privileged Account Activity Monitoring Reports
executionEvidence.description: Reports showing: privileged account activities logged, security functions performed (account creation, permission changes, security configuration), security-relevant information accessed, suspicious activity flagged, date and time of activities
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST Discussion states privileged accounts access 'security functions or security-relevant information'; monitoring proves privileged accounts used only for intended security purposes

executionEvidence.name: Quarterly Privileged Account Review Reports
executionEvidence.description: Reports showing: all privileged accounts re-certified for continued need, account holders validated as still requiring elevated access, unused privileged accounts removed, role changes triggering privilege removal, reviewer signatures
executionEvidence.rationale: Maintains restriction of privileged accounts per requirement (a); quarterly re-certification prevents accumulation of unnecessary privileged accounts

operationalActivities: Restrict privileged accounts to specifically authorized personnel and roles
Document compelling operational needs before granting privileged access
Apply enhanced scrutiny to all privileged account requests
Require administrators to use non-privileged accounts for routine work
Require privileged accounts only when performing security functions
Limit privileged account usage to accessing security-relevant information
Monitor privileged account activities weekly for inappropriate usage
Review privileged account inventory quarterly for appropriateness
Remove privileged access when no longer required by job role
Re-certify all privileged accounts quarterly for continued need
Investigate violations of privileged account usage policies
